ODAG.Description: On-Demand App Generation (ODAG) allows users to generate smaller, optimized applications dynamically from a large dataset, improving performance while ensuring detailed analysis only when needed.

Implementation.Description:
Implementing On-Demand App Generation (ODAG) in Qlik Cloud enables users to explore large datasets efficiently by generating smaller, purpose-built apps based on specific selections. This reduces system load and enhances performance, especially when working with big data sources.

Key Steps in ODAG Implementation

  1. Create a Selection App
    This is a lightweight app connected to your large data source. It provides filters or selection options to the user (e.g., choose a Region, Year, Product). It should not load detailed data, only metadata or summarized data to aid selection.
  2. Create a Template App
    This app contains the detailed charts, KPIs, and scripts meant for deep-dive analysis. It is parameterized using ODAG binding fields like $(odag_FIELDNAME), which will be replaced during generation.
  3. Set Up ODAG Link in Qlik Cloud
    Go to ODAG Links section in the Qlik Management Console (QMC) or App settings. Create a new ODAG link:
    • Source: Selection App
    • Target: Template App
    • Bind fields between the two (e.g., Region → odag_REGION)
  4. Use ODAG API or UI Integration (Optional)
    You can call ODAG programmatically using REST APIs. Integrate ODAG flows into mashups or portals using the Qlik Capability APIs.
  5. Test and Validate
    Ensure parameter values from the selection app are passed correctly. Check the script in the template app successfully pulls filtered data. Validate performance, access control, and data consistency.

Basic Example: Sales Analysis

Use Case: A user wants to analyze sales for a specific region and year.

  • Selection App: Fields: Region, Year
    User selects Region = "West" and Year = 2023
  • Template App Load Script:
LOAD *  
FROM [lib://Data/Sales.qvd]  
WHERE Region = '$(odag_REGION)' AND Year = $(odag_YEAR);
  • ODAG Link Binding:
    • Region → odag_REGION
    • Year → odag_YEAR
  • Result: When the user clicks “Generate App,” a new app is created with only sales data for West region in 2023, speeding up performance and reducing memory usage.

Best Practices for ODAG in Qlik Cloud.Description:
When using On-Demand App Generation (ODAG) in Qlik Cloud, adhering to best practices ensures optimal performance, maintainability, and a better user experience.

Best Practices:

  1. Design Efficient Selection Apps
    Keep selection apps lightweight; avoid loading large volumes of data. Use aggregated or summarized views to guide user selections effectively.
  2. Use Clear and Meaningful Bind Fields
    Name ODAG bind fields clearly (e.g., odag_REGION, odag_YEAR) to improve script readability and reduce confusion during mapping.
  3. Optimize Template App Load Scripts
    Validate and sanitize user input in the load script using default values or validation logic. Limit the number of rows fetched in the template app using WHERE clauses and conditions.
  4. Monitor App Generation and Resource Usage
    Use Qlik Cloud monitoring tools to track ODAG app generation requests and ensure resource limits are not exceeded. Archive or delete ODAG-generated apps periodically to maintain a clean workspace.
  5. Control Access and Permissions
    Secure both selection and template apps using section access and space-level permissions. Restrict ODAG link visibility to relevant user groups only.
  6. Test with Real User Scenarios
    Simulate real user selections to verify the flow and confirm the generated apps contain expected results.
  7. Use Logging and Error Handling
    Add logging statements or debugging output to your load scripts to track parameter values and script execution flow.

By following these best practices, organizations can make the most out of ODAG’s powerful capabilities while ensuring performance and governance across their Qlik Cloud environment.
